str2: If. A primary particle of conditionality; if, whether, that, etc.

parse: Personal / Possessive Pronoun - Genitive 2nd Person Singular
str2: You. The person pronoun of the second person singular; thou.
A brother, member of the same religious community, especially a fellow-Christian. A brother near or remote.

parse: Verb - Present Indicative Middle or Passive - 3rd Person Singular
str2: To pain, grieve, vex. From lupe; to distress; reflexively or passively, to be sad.
A primary preposition denoting the channel of an act; through.
Food of any kind. From the base of bibrosko; food, especially articles allowed or forbidden by the Jewish law.

parse: Verb - Present Indicative Active - 2nd Person Singular
str2: From peri and pateo; to tread all around, i.e. Walk at large; figuratively, to live, deport oneself, follow.
A primary particle; down, in varied relations (genitive, dative or accusative) with which it is joined).
From agapao; love, i.e. Affection or benevolence; specially a love-feast.
Not, lest. A primary particle of qualified negation; not, lest; also (whereas ou expects an affirmative one) whether.
The, the definite article. Including the feminine he, and the neuter to in all their inflections; the definite article; the.
Food of any kind. From the base of bibrosko; food, especially articles allowed or forbidden by the Jewish law.

parse: Verb - Present Imperative Active - 2nd Person Singular
str2: From apo and the base of olethros; to destroy fully, literally or figuratively.

parse: Personal / Possessive Pronoun - Genitive 2nd Person Singular
str2: You. The person pronoun of the second person singular; thou.
That, that one there, yonder. From ekei; that one (neuter) thing); often intensified by the article prefixed.
Gen: in behalf of; acc: above.

parse: Personal / Relative Pronoun - Genitive Masculine Singular

str2: Anointed One; the Messiah, the Christ. From chrio; Anointed One, i.e. The Messiah, an epithet of Jesus.

parse: Verb - Aorist Indicative Active - 3rd Person Singular
str2: To be dying, be about to die, wither, decay. From apo and thnesko; to die off.
